Can you cure aging?  Given that the process of cell senescence is irreversible AND all cells go through cellular senescence. THEN  if  aging is only caused by  senescence  THEN  there is no cure for aging. QED  However, one can slow down the  rate of aging. FWIW: We now know that telomere shortening is only consequence  of aging but not the cause aging.  The cause of aging and the way the body prevents it is more complicated than anything I can write up in the comments here. The world will starve, extreme weather will occur, and other diseases like corona virus will run rampant. Millions upon millions of people will have to move some where else because of rising sea levels, creating even less space in the already overpopulated earth, if we don't find a new solution to plastic soon we won't have much of an ocean anyway, but more of a giant floating soup of rubbish, and many countries who heavily rely on seafood to feed their population will be in big trouble. And there are now talk arising (I don't exactly know if it's true) that humans will soon run out of water to drink. You would have to live through all of this, being immortal, unless you died from starvation or something, I believe this would suck. The vast majority of medical research is now done by for-profit corporations that seek formulas that they can patent and convert into maximum revenue. It's not at all in their interest to cure problems in their customers. They much prefer to offer things that make you feel some relief with an acceptable amount of side effects especially if they may subsequently offer another treatment to mitigate the side effects.

Imagine if university labs were still mostly publicly funded for the betterment of humanity instead of for production of revenue generating patent medicines. Just the tendency towards working in secret and never sharing results with colleagues because of intellectual property rights owned by private sponsors is a detriment to better progress.

I’m 40 and have a DNR because of chronic illnesses that cause pain. I don’t want to be a burden on my family should I recover after a coma or CPR and be mentally or physically retarded. Very very few individuals survive CPR with their mind in tact. At some point during all our lives death becomes a mercy, often that age is in the 80’s or even 90’s.
Yes I still fear death, I don’t wish for it or do anything to expedite my end. I have few regrets in life and I know my family would be ok if I passed on today knowing I’m no longer in pain.
Some would still scream that I’m selfish for having the DNR equating it to the promise of a future suicide on paper. The most painful thing to deal with comes from family and friends who treat me like I’m already dead because I have a DNR. Psychologically I think it’s because no one likes talking about mortality these days especially about loved ones and I shocked them getting one approved by my doctors at my age (with multiple rare illnesses and failed brain surgery).
I highly recommend everyone do an Advance Directive so your family and loved ones know how you want to be treated should you fall into a vegetative state or become terminally ill and need someone to take over your affairs.

There is one possible life extension approach with currently existing technology though it does involve dying. After your death, have your brain sliced in 20nm slices and digitally photographed in high resolution thereby preserving your neural networks digitally as close to life without killing you before you would've otherwise die. Then, if you've left a large enough trust fund to simulate your neural networks on computers and to research how to interface the simulation with either the real world or a simulated world and to repair whatever may have been damaged in death then you could conceivably live indefinitely or at least a version of you could live indefinitely.

This would be better than cryonics because with cryonics you only have one attempt at resurrection whereas with a digital record of your neural networks there can be an infinite number of attempts plus computer technology advances more quickly than medical and virtual environments and associated computer technology are funded by the video gaming industry.

It would probably be wise to also keep journals and vlogs for your reanimated self to peruse. It may be possible to repair cognitive functions damaged by death but not necessarily memory lost by death so it's best to assume that your reanimated self would only have at best partial memories of your life.

Senescent Cells don't cause extensive Tissue Damage like what you mentioned, they , there are way more important factors such as the Autophagy pathway... Teleromase Shortening is quite an important factor in ageing but it does the damage by rendering Cells unable to replicate and thus slows healing or regeneration on a macroscopic scale, not by turning the Cell into a harmful one that damages surrounding Cells. We still have things like Genetic Methylation too. Also, even creatures with Cells not bound by the Hayflick Limit (Cells replicate infinitely and don't become Senescent) still age and die, so only killing off Senescent Cells or giving cells immortality won't cut it. There's something that we just haven't seen yet that is causing ageing.

There's a bit of a misconception about aging, namely that if we we're to keep 100% healthy throughout our lives, that'd we'd never die from aging since its a process of gradual buildup of damage inside a persons cells. Longevity is a consequence of being healthy. Dr Aubrey de Gray laid out the whole thing in his "Roadmap to aging" , as to basically what bases we'd have to cover from a medical standpoint to reach that point. But the greatest barrier to the development of the technology won't be the technology itself, but our own society. It took a total of 32 years to get a life-saving cure for stroke's to even pop up on the medical radar, half of which was trying to get it through the FDA in the US. An even so, not many hospitals carry it, despite the myriad of other drugs that are in circulation that at best lessen the impact,  does nothing, or even makes the problem worse. Hopefully demand for something like this will help push it through, if not, then it might actually take a hundred years after its invented for it to move past all the bureaucratic bullshit and become wildly available.

I received this email recently from the site Ask a Mathematician, Ask a Physicist:

What are "actual pictures" of atoms actually pictures of?.

Physicist:
Actual pictures of atoms aren’t actually pictures at all.
There are a few good rules of thumb in physics. Among the best is:
light acts like you’d expect on scales well above its wavelength and
acts weird on scales below. In order to take a picture of a thing you
need light to bounce …

The only thing physicists have actually seen is basically a computer
image, not the real image, and second, they observe electric fields,
not the particle itself. They do not observe particles themselves;
they are able to observe only the field. However this alone does not
prove anything, but that the electric energy field exists and that’s
about it---no atoms, no photons, no electrons, no quarks. no nothing.
So no, particles do not exist. Particles exist only inside
mathematical abstractions and nothing more and nothing else. We don’t
know what actually exists in the real world, except that there are
energy fields---electric, magnetic and all other forms and all other
kinds of energy fields.

I forgot to add what exactly is visualized with all these microscopes
including STM--the scanning tunneling microscope. What is visualized
is the charge density of the electric field.
Basically you observe vibrations---electric vibrations.
You haven’t seen an atom either. You’ve seen an image you assume to be
an atom, but it is simply an instrument’s representation of the atom.
It is not the atom itself.

These techniques aren’t actually “visual” like microscopes we work
with in biology classes. Microscopes use lenses and light to help zoom
and focus on small objects. Electron microscopes, on the other hand,
use quantum scattering theory to construct the shape of small objects,
then the data is transferred to a computer to create a model. The
wavelengths of visible light ranges on the order of ~370nm to 750nm.
These are all MUCH larger than many particles of interest (and way too
large to view atoms, which are on the order of Angstroms–0.1nm).
Scientists need to be creative to be able to “see” atoms.

So, no, scanning tunneling microscopes and atomic force microscopes
did not prove the existence of atoms.

example. But he can accept the risk of disease stoically. It is part of the nature of things, it is no one’s fault, unless it is the fault of some imaginary, impersonal demon. But threats to the modern individual tend to be MAN-MADE. They are not the results of chance but are IMPOSED on him by other persons whose decisions he, as an individual, is unable to influence. Consequently he feels frustrated, humiliated and angry.
Thus primitive man for the most part has his security in his own hands (either as an individual or as a member of a SMALL group) whereas the security of modern man is in the hands of persons or organizations that are too remote or too large for him to be able personally to influence them. So modern man’s drive for security tends to fall into groups 1 and 3; in some areas (food, shelter etc.) his security is assured at the cost of only trivial effort, whereas in other areas he CANNOT attain security. (The foregoing greatly simplifies the real situation, but it does indicate in a rough, general way how the condition of modern man differs from that of primitive man.)

Let only people in their 40s reproduce so that only those who are healthy enough at that age pass their genes. The next generation, having inherited traits of their parents, will more likely be able to reproduce at 40.

However, due to the mutability of the DNA, there'll be individuals who will be capable of procreating at, say, 45 (also some incapable at 35).

Continue raising the minimum age for making babies with each successive generation, so that you choose only the people healthy enough at the selected age to pass their genetic material.

With such artificial selection (eugenics), you can ensure that people that are hundred (or beyond) are healthy enough to reproduce (and are therefore relatively resistant to disease and aging).

I understand that this can be highly unethical and that Hitler abused eugenics to bring genocide. I brought it up just for theoretical knowledge, which in the least case explains artificial selection to anyone that previously was unaware.

As he phrases it, we have a sort of stockholm syndrome with death, where because we can't avoid it we have convinced ourselves that it is a good thing. It's just a coping mechanism to deal with our abusive relationship with the universe where it springs us into existence full of goals and ambitions and desires, but gives us a limited time to achieve them, growing more and more capable for like 1/4 of our life but then spending the rest of it rotting until we fall apart. Life is not meaningful because of death, it has it's own meaning.

For those of you concerned about the ethics of stem cells, specifically, how they are harvested, please understand that the media (and the scientific community at large) has really hyped up the importance of embryonic stems cells. Stem cells can be found in many human body parts , and in fact, currently, the most effective and dependable stems cells are not embryonic ones, but retinal ones. Not only that, but adult stems cells (including the dependable, flexible and empirically effective retinal stem cell) can be replicated by huge amounts in stem cell cultures AND be programmed backing into their embryonic state! So Stem cell harvesting does not equal human embryo harvesting.

There is a ton of research for this, but to prove I'm not just making this up: https://www.nature.com/news/japanese-man-is-first-to-receive-reprogrammed-stem-cells-from-another-person-1.21730

Having sex preserves telomeres.  In addition to the others in the long, long list of health benefits of frequent sexual activity, some research was done recently specifically on its effects on telomeres.  The study was actually expecting to discover that relationship satisfaction was more important than sexual activity, but the actual results showed that relationship satisfaction is less important and that the more frequently you have sex the longer your telomeres will remain.  In other words, sexual abstinence causes premature telomere shortening and premature aging if you consider being sexually active to be the 'normal' state of human beings.  I've been watching for years and am curious how long the list of health dangers of abstinence needs to become before people start realizing it for the unhealthy neurosis it is.

I am an animal rights advocate. Because of species difference, positive results in animals cannot necessarily be replicated in humans. For instance, it's a fact that scientists have been able to cure mice of cancer for decades now but this success has not been able to be transferred over to people. I think that experimentation on animals should stop immediately because it is not doing us (or the animals for that matter) any good. Also, I believe that these days there are software programs that can accurately simulate, analyse and assess experimenting on humans. This would also have the extra benefit of resolving the ethical dilemma of possibly harming people through live experiments.

So, while it may come about within the life times of some of the younger among us, it would not come around within time to actually help/support people currently alive.

The problem with stem cells is that it can be kind of unethical. There are two general types of stem cells, embryonic stem cells and adult stem cells. Adult cells  are obviously found in adults, teens, etc, and they can only become a specific type of cell, this limits their usages, however they can still be useful, and of you need them, you would have to find a donor, and now that this donor has lost some stem cells, it is likely they are going to need some soon. Embryonic stem cells are pluripotent, meaning they can become many types of cells, these are the more useful ones, but as the title implies, they only come from embryos (and young, young babies), and if you extract them, it will likely damage them in the future. The difference is that this time, it was involuntary.

You are saying "human trials are about to begin".  Humans are not lab mice with 2 year lifespans.  The fundamental problem is that a meaningful study on a single anti-aging treatment in a being where aging effects take place over decades MUST take at least decades to conduct.  It'd take several rounds of such studies to know for sure that any such treatment is doing more good than harm, or which combination would be best for a given patient.  That means we are at least 100 years from a meaningful treatment for aging in humans.

Maybe not in our lifetimes however if we were to start human testing in let's say 10 years then we'd most likely test a variety of people on the treatment for the rest of their lives, which if it goes correctly could be 120 years on average. Now we need to also test if this was just a coincidence, or a result of other things currently happening at the time, such as disease, better medicine, temperature change, etc. After all this we should have enough info to start treating people if the side effects aren't terribly bad, and at the same time we'll need to start working out these issues and testing variants of the treatment to see what works best. Now at this point it would have been around 200 years, just to be able to have a variant that works fairly well with (most likely) some side effects, and this is one of the best case scenarios I can think of where the age range of the applicants is around 40-90 years old, so I'm not even thinking of doing tests on children to see if starting earlier helps any... Death is almost like a cure for a species. Without death, new generations of organisms wouldn't come along. Death is the reason organisms and species can adapt to their environment: A population with members less adapted to an environment will die out, leaving the more fit to reproduce, and evolving the species over many generations. Humans have already pretty much halted natural selection, and if death was to be eliminated, the human species would be doomed as the Earth's environment keeps changing.

Few problems though, it is likely only going to be available to the rich (at least at first), then you've got the population problem. On top of that people will be working until older ages leaving less jobs for new generations, not to mention other advances are going to reduce employment numbers as well.

Do we really need to live longer? We should focus on making our 80 years on earth more fulfilling as opposed to just extending it. If we could have the best of both worlds, that being live 120 years of fulfilling life - then sure. In reality we get one or the other.

Lifespans already cause economic problems, it will be untenable when they double. Many govts have to spend a 3rd of their budget on pensions, if a demographic shift makes the majority pensioners then you have an economic crisis like Japan has now. Either you raise retirement age and reduce jobs for the young, or the old get replaced by young workers on lower salaries and you have senescent unemployment.

Hello Kurzgesagt. You've mentioned that Stem Cell is a proof of concept in theory. This is not true. It is actually being performed in China at the moment and had already shown a significant in the slowdown of aging and curing of certain diseases. My family had be in this business since year 2013 and it had grown successfully and cured hundreds of patients. The main application really required people to accept and understand the benefits of stem cells and how it work. It would need people to understand to gain stem cells, it does not mean to take it from a embryo. We can use our own or ones from umbilical cord that were not stored. It is effective, and like you've mentioned in the video, can help to rejuvenate and increase the metabolism of cells around it.

For those who think they'll have a chance, I am sorry to inform you that the process takes a long time. It can range from 4 month to a year before it really helps you to stop aging. You have to constantly take injection from Stem Cells therapy and have a good diet. In order words, if you don't have the money to spend on this treatment, tough luck. I do believe that in the future when this can be mass produced, people can have a choice of either being young at the age of 20 or just keep aging. Current technology can't stop people from aging, but it does slow it down significantly. You can't beat nature, but you can alway postpone the final time.

And even if NAD+ is given from the outside if the cell is already lacking the mechanisms to metabolize NAD+/NADH+H+ (as that‘s the requirement for it needing outside NAD+). As NAD+ is a key factor in basic cellular respiration the only mechanism I can think of that injecting it into your system actually helps is that by using the concentration gradient, the systems is more likely to respond by shifting NAD+ to its reduced form. But if perhaps the cells are already lacking the necessary enzymes to guarantee efficient cellular respiration, adding more NAD+ is only good until the maximum number of active centers in the enzymes are working at the same time.
As such it‘s only putting more educts into a old machine that‘s in the process of breaking down and hoping that the products are more plentiful and shiny.

Your question is philosophical ("What if we could stop aging forever?") - and it is also not possible to answer in a literal sense.

The Philosophical
What you are asking (not that you gave it much thought) is, "What next?" Since you did not even give the question much thought, I'll assume that you did not even get around to thinking about the answer (lucky you have me). The answer is "Engage in the Great Struggle". I'll let you look that up (if my answer has hit Google yet - 10% chance - it is rather new).

The Literal
Your oversight (lack of thought) here is in using 'forever', which is not possible to reach (meaning you will never reach and 'end point' where you can look back and say, "Ah, finally, I've reached 'forever'") (hence my 'Great Struggle' - which is, in other words, a 'Perpetual Struggle') (which is a great challenge, you must admit, hence 'great'). If you haven't found the answer on Google, here it is: The 'Great Struggle' entails perpetually increasing our 'bounds of security' against a harsh and deadly universe. Enlightened alien beings already know this, foolish (meaning unenlightened) humans do not (greetings, foolish human - here's some enlightenment).

As for 'curing' death, even that may be a misperception leading us down wrong paths. Maybe the right word is 'solving death'. For example, say 'death' is cause by radiation from the sun and the interior of the earth. Then the 'solution' would be to distance ourselves from the radiation (such as setting ourselves up in interstellar, if not intergalactic, space). Perhaps this is why we have not been 'visited' by 'intelligent' aliens (woe to us if we are visited by unenlightened aliens with advanced technology) - they are keeping their distance from the radiation. This is just one example, but it demonstrates that 'death' may be a simple 'cure' or 'solution', we simply are not looking at it right.

Good topic - thanks for the mental stimulation (and now I'll watch your video, knowing in advance that you will not come anywhere near my advanced thinking).

On Increasing 'Healthspans'

Your video covers health spans, but what about 'consciousness' spans - meaning, if you are able to reduce the amount of sleep you need, your 'conscious' life will be extended by a good percentage, and you will also have more 'peak' hours (with which you could address the Great Struggle, if you were enlightened, but you're not - so they would merely be wasted).

The Last Mistake You Make

The last mistake you make in this video is focusing on technology and medicine, when, as I've just illustrated, the root of the problem is philosophical - why even bother to extend life if it is going to be wasted on foolish, clueless endeavors? It is a world for the depraved, who will dominate such a world. Isn't that a pleasant prospect? (answer: no, it is not, and it illustrates how clueless science really is without an adequate philosophy behind it (such as mine)).

We are already concerned about the overpopulation on earth (although this will eventually peak and then decline as pointed out in another video of Kurzgesagt). Will we end up with more a less a static population of the same individuals and will these people be able to drive innovation and advancements of the human kind in the same way? The only way to reach any "true" level of biological immortality is indeed to combine methods. However, the most effective of these methods requires that we be able to both repair out telomeres, but also find better ways of dealing with the inevitable increase in cancer that comes with making our cells functionally immortal.

With these sorts of treatments, human beings could all conceivably live at least to be 100 years old in good health. Of course, we'll eventually hit other problems in our biology that tend to be glossed over by the fact that we die to other things more quickly.

For example: mutations in your cells that are naturally occurring and are unique to individual cells essentially lead to the cells in your body being less and less "uniform" as you age. This isn't something you can fix through simple methods. The way that nature fixes this problem is through reproduction, and by making sure each new "body" starts with only a single cell with a specific set of DNA, but we don't have that option if we're looking to live longer.

Fixing THAT problem I can see as being far more complicated. We would need to find a way to genetically engineer our cells on the fly - perhaps having genetically engineered special cells or such that go around and make sure that the DNA within the cells of your body "match" some kind of master DNA record. Then either destroying cells that do not, or replacing their DNA with the correct copy. Of course - where would this record be stored? If it was stored in your body, it would have the same fundamental risk of being "corrupted" over time.

Perhaps this is where technology besides bioengineering could come in? If we had a cybernetic implant for example that held a master DNA record for your body, and was able to release nanomachines or simply inform your body of what DNA is "normal" for its cells, then all would be well. This method also would also be a cure for cancer, as a side note, since cancerous cells only are cancerous due to faulty DNA.

Although: how to read the DNA of a given cell on a nano-scale while not disrupting the function of said cell is another story of its own. Perhaps the way that this could be done is by essentially telling a given cell that is being checked to go through a certain kind of mitosis, so that any kind of damage would only be to the "copied" cell. If the cell was not able to undergo mitosis as requested, or the DNA did not match the master "record," the cell would be destroyed.

I think this would be most efficient by essentially just genetically engineering our immune system to perform this function. Now that I think about it as well, if you had enough copies of the "master DNA record" within your body to be checked, and those records THEMSELVES were consistently being compared against the "majority," no amount of mutation through radiation or such would be enough to damage the "true record" in question.

Just rambling here, but this stuff is exciting to think about. Making it actually "work" of course is a whole other story.

The general consensus is that (at least for now) this stuff will only be available to the extremely rich. I disagree - I see no reason for it to be more expensive or difficult than other forms of treatment; the fact that we hold one enzyme to be particularly valuable because it causes us to live longer does not make it any more difficult to research and develop than any other enzyme.

Take insulin. We currently produce insulin via genetically modified bacteria, and it is enough for an extremely large number of people. We could probably do exactly the same thing with the healthspan-increasers (we need a name for these), and although the price would start out high, due to little supply and the fact that the first company to commercialise it will have a monopoly on it, the rules of supply and demand, competition, and capitalism in general, will hopefully bring it down to close its actual cost to produce.

This is all fine and good in like 10 years when these are developed but you forgot to mention what everyone can do right now to extend their lifespan and healthspan: calorie restriction. Or more accurately protein restriction. Calorie restriction is currently being researched for its benefits in slowing aging, and in almost every animal model a 30% reduction in caloric intake returns a 30% increase in healthy lifespan.  One of the theories for the mechanism of this effect is autophagy, where in a mild protein deficiency the body repairs damage rather than replaces cells, slowing the depletion of telomeres. Many of the cultures known for their longevity like okinawans had traditional diets mildly restrictive in protein.

If you are worried about the paper "It's mathematically impossible to beat aging, scientists say"
Read deeper into the ORIGINAL source paper. In the discussion it actually says:

"Mechanisms such as immune function, redundancy of cancer suppression genes, and tissue structure affect the rate at which cell cooperation degrades (61, 62). This can be captured in our numerical model either as change in the rates of degradation μv and μc or as a shift from a one- or two-hit model to a multihit model, and in our analytical model as either the magnitude of mutational effects on each of the two traits or in the shape of the {z,f} → {v,c} map and resulting coordinate system. Such mechanisms might significantly slow aging, perhaps even to NEGLIGIBLE RATES. Our model does not inform the magnitude of age-related decline, only its inevitability."

Here is the original paper, read the discussion:

1) "Aging is the root of almost all diseases".
False. Aging is actually the consequence of most diseases. Most people assume that Aging Cells are what causes Aging of the body, but the truth is, that's a total myth. Most of the aging is caused by organ failures, in which cells are perfectly fine, but some Pathogenic Noxa caused a disfunction, of which the repair is more and more difficult over time. Which is why there is no cure for Aging, it would actually mean "Cure for everything".
2) Killing Senescent Cells is not a solution for infinite biological life (Aka no Aging), because Thelomeres still shorten everytime cells reproduce. We will just live longer, until most of them become senescent cells. At which point we will have no way to regenerate everything.
3) Stem cells might cope for problem n 1, but they are not eternal helpers (if they were, we would already be immortal. Evolution is not stupid). Stem cells Also age, and they cannot reproduce for indefinite time.

We're just biological machines operating along the rails of our genetic code.  But code can be altered, and parts of a machine can be replaced/improved upon.  We see negligibly senescent creatures in nature--lobsters, hydra, tortoises, etc.  Ergo, we can be pretty certain that there's nothing in the laws of nature preventing us from achieving it as well.   It would be by our own design rather than as an evolutionary boon, but harnessing/mimicing the underlying mechanism of action of the abilities of other creatures is one of the things that we do best.  Flight is a good example.  We've seen birds flying since the beginning, and this simple act of observation inspired our ancestors to try and figure out the secret for themselves because they knew that it should be possible for us to achieve as well.  "If they can do it, why can't we?"  And eventually, of course, we did.  Now we can circumnavigate the entire globe in time spans measured in hours.

There are some serious limitations to be aware of before you get your hopes up. Take senescent cells, for example. Killing a large number of cells all at once can be potentially fatal, meaning that this will be of less value to those who are already old. Additionally, senescent cells play an essential role in wound healing. This means that in addition to the complications that can arise from killing too many at once you'd also be faced with slower recovery if you survive. On the plus side, it would definitely be of value to those are are middle aged at least and if the dosage can be controlled to minimize cell death to a gradual occurrence might eventually be of use to those who are currently elderly. While the peptide would be destroyed by digestion, injection is not the only possible route of delivery. Inhalation can also work, with a nasal spray being a possible route to ensure that it also gets delivered to brain cells directly.

In regards to stem cells, the embryonic stem cells are actually of less value than your own adult stem cells. Studies attempting to use them have had very mixed results. However, if you save the adult stem cells from the cut umbilical cord it can be of use later. Unfortunately, although it's possible to culture adult stem cells in the lab, I can't seem to find a single lab willing to do so - and I'm a genetics major! All of the labs I spoke with seem limited to extraction from one part of the body and either storage or immediate re-injection. They told me it was illegal, so it might be a consequence of laws aimed at stopping embryonic stem cell research (out of concern for unborn children) spilling into adult stem cell research (that does not harm children). This is problematic, because to get the most benefit from a stem cell injection you need to extract them when healthy and culture them for later re-injection. Your stem cells can even be programmed prior to re-injection, such as making them immune to HIV infection. Another issue is that as stem cells are exposed to the environment and undergo replications that experience epigentic changes - many of them harmful - so you'd really need a few lines backed up. You'd also want to extract a special kind of stem cell from the bone marrow that wouldn't have undergone any divisions or epigenetic alteration to start from if you didn't have your cells collected at birth.

There are attempts for creating a national stem cell bank based on the premise that only a limited number of types will be needed for everything, but there are risks even here. If, hypothetically, you started to get extremely high levels of stem cell injections on a regular basis it could potentially inhibit the release of your own stem cells. While this would be great if you were TRYING to replace your cells over time with genetically modified cells, this is probably not a good thing if you are just getting a cocktail of many different people's DNA. Truth is, I have no idea what would result from such a scenario, but I'd err on the side of caution.

Another area of study not mentioned in this video is that there are regenerative compounds in blood that decline over time. When young blood from a young mouse was transferred to an old mouse the biological age of it's organs ended up matching that of the younger mouse. However, in that case they surgically connected the vascular system of the two mice so the particles in the old mouse blood may have been filtered by the younger mouse, or that it was an issue of quantity. A followup study found that the levels which would be safe on humans didn't have a statistically meaningful impact. This is in large part because a full blood replacement from someone of different genetics can be harmful, whereas the mice used in studies are so genetically similar they might as well be clones. Of course, that new study doesn't discount the possibility of storing large quantities of your own blood over time and then reinjecting with it later to flush the system and restore the youthful state. It also doesn't discount that, when you have to get a large blood transfusion anyway, the age of the donor might actually be important, but we have no way of testing either because personal blood storage at those volumes is rare and blood donation doesn't log the age of the donor (although, imho, it should at least record the age group of donors, especially considering that most ends up being sold for medical studies rather than given to people in need)

Overall though, I'd say that a nasal spray with a cocktail of peptides, special proteins for brain function, NAD+, and adult stem cells taken as a twice daily medication would be extremely valuable. Although, they'd have the logistical issue of needing to either group the dose into stem cell types (don't take someone else's nasal spray!) or have it specially made from your own stem cells sent to a lab. Might be more expensive, but then every cell and protein going in would be made from your own genetic information for maximum benefit.

I've noticed a decent amount of comments on this and videos similar concerning overpopulation. Of the many obstacles humanity has to overcome, living space will not be one of them unless we exceed the hundreds of trillions of individuals, and that is presuming we never inhabit orbital stations, the moon, etc.

Perhaps this would be a good topic for Kurzgesagt to cover, bringing the concepts of things like arcologies and ecumenopolises to a wider audience. Could also offer you a good collab opportunity with Isaac Arthur or someone similar :D

If I recall you guys already did an overpopulation episode, but it was more focused on the trends in fertility rates based on a country's modernization. Mayhaps this would be a good spiritual successor, to show people that space should never realistically be a concern, but the problems of food and energy very well can be (if the research is not allowed!).

Humanity's greatest challenge in this regard will always be food, not space, and when we begin to embrace GMOs for the potential they have, we could very well solve that issue within a decade. Add into the mix an extended lifespan, and we very well could be living in the dawn of the next golden age of technology and development.

...Of course if we figure out fusion.....none of this matters realistically since we would have infinite power on the timescale of whatever length our civilization persists, but i digress.
